bibl.title: Letter from Leonard Wood to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 7, 1925

div1.p: Wood asks Kean to check over his memorandum regarding yellow fever in Cuba for any errors or inaccuracies. Wood wants to make sure proper credit is given to Havard and Kean for their work in Havana, Cuba. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Leonard Wood to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 7, 1925
div1.opener:
Gr
Office of the Governor-General
Manila
September 7, 1925.
Dear Kean:
div1.p:
I am sending you herewith a memorandum
for Mr. Mark Sullivan together with a copy of my
letter to him.

Mr. Sullivan has written me for expres-
sion of opinion on a portion of a manuscript
dealing with the history of the United States
which he is writing, in which he deals with the
yellow fever work in Cuba. He is naturally an-
xious to present the matter correctly.

I have given him your address and the
address of Colonel Havard. I wish you would read
over the memorandum and if there is any error in
fact of such a character that it should not be
sent to Sullivan, please send it back to me with
your comment. If the memorandum is substantially
correct, send it on to Sullivan.

I am also inclosing copy of a memorandum which
General Dorey has prepared for Mr. Sullivan in
connection with the same matter - yellow fever
in Cuba, especially Havana.

I want to give Havard full credit for
the work he did and give you full credit for your
most valuable services not only with Reed but
later on with Gorgas in connection with Gorgas'
work dealing with yellow fever in Cuba, especially
Havana, during the first intervention and your work
in charge of general sanitation during the second
intervention.

I am writing Sullivan that I have sent
this memorandum to you so that he will know
where it is in case of any delay. I am also
referring Sullivan to your excellent review
of the Gorgas Book in the March number of the
Military Surgeon.

Of course there were lots of other good
men like Agremonte who also did most excellent work
but I have not attempted to go into their ser-
vices in the inclosed memorandum.

With kind regards to you and Mrs. Kean,
in which Mrs. Wood and Dorey join, as ever,
div1.closer:
Faithfully yours, Leonard Wood Brig. Gen. Jefferson R. Kean,
1233 31st Street,
Washington, D.C.
